channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-8397] improve unit-test coverage of package org.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.metrics (0.94)
item.description:
The patch suggests new test that elevates unit-test coverage of package org.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.metrics .
The patch is applicable to branch 0.94 only.
item.summary: improve unit-test coverage of package org.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.metrics (0.94)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:

patch is not applied in verification since it is for 0.94 only.
Thanks for the patch Ivan. Add a license to your new class – see how other source files do it – and we should be good to go.
Sure, added the header.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12580064/HBASE-8397-0.94--N5.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 2 new or modified tests.

-1 patch. The patch command could not apply the patch.

Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5400//console

This message is automatically generated.
+1 on patch.

I'm not a big fan of anything that does sleep.(SOME SET NUMBER). That idiom has been the cause of a lot of test flakyness in the past. What do you think of doing a loop while/sleep , with a timeout on the test?

Hi, Elliot,
in this case we actually don't wait for anything with sleep(). Here we just need to have the time between 2 invocations of masterMetrics.doUpdates() to be greater or equal than 1 second, otherwise we cannot get non-zero metric rate value. The most straight and simple way to achieve this is Thread.sleep(1000). Sure, I can substitute that with while/sleep, but why that is better?
Timeout on the test can also be added, but in this case it seems that there is no real opportunity to hang up.
Added more diagnostics into the test.

+1

Thanks for the review, Stack.

@Ivan:
Mind taking a look ?
Reverted for now.

HBASE-8397 Revert due to test failure in secure build (tedyu: rev 1535503)

  • /hbase/branches/0.94/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/master/metrics/MasterMetrics.java
  • /hbase/branches/0.94/src/test/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/master/metrics/TestMasterStatistics.java

FAILURE: Integrated in HBase-0.94 #1182 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-0.94/1182/)
HBASE-8397 Revert due to test failure in secure build (tedyu: rev 1535503)

  • /hbase/branches/0.94/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/master/metrics/MasterMetrics.java
  • /hbase/branches/0.94/src/test/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/master/metrics/TestMasterStatistics.java
Reopened due to the revert.
And moved to 0.94.14.
Ran TestMasterStatistics using security profile on Mac but didn't reproduce the test failure.

Hi, Ted,
Actually I couldn't reproduce the issue also , even with -Psecurity.
I have 2 ideas why that failure could happen:
1) the test was annotated "@Category(SmallTests)" , so it might have been executed together with other tests, that could affect the behavior.
2) the test might have "/hadoop-metrics.properties" resource in the classpath, so it might have started the metrics update timer thread, that could affect the behavior.
So, I updated the patch (HBASE-83970.94-N7.patch) with the following changes: (1) assigned the test to @MediumTests, (2) added code to ensure that the metrics use NullContext which never starts the update thread.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12611443/HBASE-8397-0.94--N7.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 3 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop1.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.0 profile.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

-1 javadoc. The javadoc tool appears to have generated 1 warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

-1 findbugs. The patch appears to introduce 1 new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

-1 site. The patch appears to cause mvn site goal to fail.

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .
